title: AMD Ryzen 5 5600G: Budget Pack-a-Punch!
tags: how to build a gaming pc
description: SPONSOR: Learn more about AMD's latest Ryzen 5000 series APUs:   AMD's latest APUs pack one heck of a punch thanks to Vega graphics cores and Zen 3 CPU architecture! Let's dive deeper.   Consider supporting us on Patreon!    PC parts list:  AMD Ryzen 5 5600G:  ASUS TUF B550M-PLUS WiFi:  16GB Silicon Power DDR4:  Cooler Master Q300L:  EVGA 500W BR:  Team Group MP33 512GB:  Graphics Card: YOU DON'T NEED ONE! :-D   My studio gear on Amazon: Sony a6600 (Primary):  Sony a6400 (Secondary):  2x Pixio PX277 Prime 165Hz IPS Monitors:  Neewer LED Lighting Kit:  Audio-Technica AT2035:  Yamaha MG10XU Mixer:  Neewer Microphone Arms:  Arrowzoom Sound-Damping Foam Panels:    Follow me on social media: TWITCH:  FACEBOOK:  TWITTER:  INSTAGRAM:    Join our public Discord server:   DISCLOSURES: All Genius links are tied to our Amazon Associate account, from which we earn a small sales commission. Links containing a 'bit.ly' reference forwarding to Newegg are tied to our Rakuten account, from which we earn a small sales commission. All sponsored links and comments will contain the word "SPONSOR" or "AD." Any additional revenue stream will be disclosed with similar verbiage.  #AMD #Ryzen
transcript: Sometimes less is more sometimes you don't need a discreet gpu for quality gaming sometimes all you need is a beefy APU. This is the AMD Ryzen 5 5600G and we've partnered with AMD to discuss its architecture and capabilities in this video and spoiler* it packs one heck of a punch for the price we wouldn't be doing this making this video if that wasn't the case. See, in a world where graphics cards are in high demand and most of us are well at least on some kind of reasonable budget releases like these are quite refreshing not only do they not break the bank at least relatively speaking they're also widely available chances are you can hop online and buy one right now without having to deal with crazy price gouging now that seems like a weird pro in 2021 but it is what it is so knowing that going into this i'd say the 5600g is a pretty darn good place to start uh for an entry-level gaming pc as it is relatively attainable in relation to most discreet graphics options out there now as for architecture and features let's start with the basic architectural layout and its advantages over previous APUs so AMD recently released two 5000 series APUs we have the 5600g this one here and the Ryzen 7 5700g. Now the 5600g if you ask me is the more i think this is the more value bang for the buck option it's got six cores 12 threads base frequency of 3.9 gigahertz max 4.4 and 19 megs of cash the 5700g on the other hand bumps things up to 8 cores and 16 threads we're talking cpu cores here and a max frequency of 4.6 gigahertz and 20 megabytes of l3 cache TDPs are identical and both have unlocked multipliers for added fun if you're into overclocking no overclocking tax you'll need to pay with either of these but apart from the obvious cp core disparity there's really only one other small difference physically between these two and that's the number of compute units see the 5600g here has seven of these and these are essentially dedicated graphics course the 5700g has eight along with a slightly higher frequency and we'd expect performance to scale roughly in line with this number so not a huge disparity in graphical horsepower though we'd expect the 5700g to have a distinct advantage in other multi-threaded applications like say video editing streaming and encoding also bear in mind that these chips are reliant on zen 3 architecture for their cpu cores which means you'll enjoy a healthy latency reduction over that of previous ap generations thanks to unified l3 cache and an 8 core per ccx right meaning core to core communication need not travel across the infinity fabric first this ultimately translates to more efficient processing time and higher frame rates in games all other things equal less latency equals good now as we just mentioned AMD decided to send us the 5600g which i would have opted for anyway seeing as though it is the more attainable chip without too large a compromise in the graphics department on paper and with it in the box you'll find a
